questions.text: In a clinical laboratory, various enzymes are employed as reagents to measure concentrations of specific substances in patient samples. These enzymatic assays provide accurate and efficient means of diagnosis and monitoring. Which of the following enzymes are examples of those used as reagents in clinical laboratory tests?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

  • Glucose oxidase is commonly used in blood glucose monitoring devices and tests due to its specificity for glucose, making it an invaluable tool for diagnosing and managing diabetes.
  • Urease is used in assays to measure urea levels in blood or urine, which can be indicative of kidney function or other metabolic conditions.
  • Cholesterol oxidase is employed in tests to determine cholesterol levels in blood, which is crucial for assessing cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 309.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. His medical history is unremarkable except for chronic alcohol misuse. Laboratory tests reveal significantly elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. Based on these findings, which condition is most commonly associated with an increase in these two enzyme levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute pancreatitis

 

Option A.

 

ACUTE PANCREATITIS:

 

  • Premature activation of trypsinogen inside the pancreas will result in the autodigestion of pancreatic cells. It is a life threatening condition.
  • SERUM LIPASE:
  • It is highly elevated in acute pancreatitis and persists for 7 – 14 days.
  • Thus, its level remains elevated for a longer period than amylase and also lipase is not increased in salivary diseases. Hence, lipase estimation has an advantage over amylase.
  • Moderately increased in carcinoma of pancreas, biliary diseases and perforating peptic ulcers.

 

SERUM AMYLASE:

 

  • It is the major enzyme which digests starch, containing the P (pancreatic) and S (salivary) iso-enzymes. Normal amylase level in serum is 50–120 units and the level rises within 5 hours of the onset of acute pancreatitis →  reaches a peak within 12hrs → returns to normal within 2–4 days of attack → when urinary amylase level rises.
  • Serum amylase is mildly increased in cholecystitis, peptic ulcer, diseases of mesentery and obstruction of intestine and no significant changes or only mild elevation is noticed in chronic pancreatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Liver cirrhosis: While liver disease can affect various enzymes, notably ALT and AST, it's not typically associated with a significant rise in amylase and lipase as seen in pancreatic conditions.

 

Option C. Bone disease: Diseases affecting bone generally lead to alterations in alkaline phosphatase, calcium, and phosphate levels, rather than amylase or lipase.

 

Option D. Gallbladder disease: Conditions like cholecystitis might cause mild elevations in amylase due to shared ducts between the liver, gallbladder, and pancreas, but the most pronounced increases are observed in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated serum amylase and lipase levels are hallmark indicators of acute pancreatitis, reflecting pancreatic inflammation or injury. These enzymes, particularly lipase, are more specific to pancreatic damage and are used clinically to confirm a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 358.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented with fever, skeletal pain, polydipsia, polyuria and multiple osteolytic lesions in pelvic bones and upper femur. There was no organomegaly or lymphadenopathy. His serum calcium levels were raised. PBS appears normal. Bone marrow: presence of blast cells. Flow cytometry indicated B-acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (B-ALL). The enzyme useful in the treatment of leukemia is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asparaginase

 

Option C.

 

Asparaginase is an enzyme used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It works by depleting the amino acid asparagine, which is necessary for the growth and proliferation of leukemia cells. As normal cells are able to synthesize asparagine, they are less affected by the enzyme, making asparaginase a targeted treatment for ALL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alpha-1-antitrypsin is a protease inhibitor and is mainly used in the treatment of conditions like emphysema associated with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, not leukemia.

 

Option B. Lipase is an enzyme that breaks down fats in the digestive system and has no therapeutic role in the treatment of leukemia.

 

Option D. Streptokinase is an enzyme used to break down blood clots (thrombolysis) and is used in the treatment of conditions such as myocardial infarction, not leukemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 308.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female has been recently diagnosed with leukemia, a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. The oncology team is considering various treatment options, including the use of therapeutic enzymes that can target specific metabolic pathways involved in cancer cell growth. Among the available enzyme-based treatments, which one is considered appropriate for managing leukemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asparaginase                                               

 

Option B.

 

  • L-asparaginase is an anticancer drug used against leukaemia and lymphomas because those cells cannot synthesize asparagine.
  • This enzyme will destroy the available asparagine in the blood causing the cancer cells to die.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is an enzyme used to break down blood clots and is typically used in the treatment of conditions like acute myocardial infarction (heart attack) or pulmonary embolism, not leukemia.

 

Option C. Urokinase: Urokinase is another thrombolytic enzyme used to dissolve blood clots. Similar to streptokinase, it is not used in the treatment of leukemia but rather in conditions where blood clots are a primary concern.

 

Option D. Both A and B: While both streptokinase and asparaginase are enzymes, only asparaginase is used in the treatment of leukemia. Streptokinase's use is unrelated to cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of asparaginase in the treatment of leukemia, specifically its mechanism of action that involves depleting asparagine to inhibit the growth of leukemia cells.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 226.

questions.text: A cardiologist is reviewing the timeline of enzyme elevation following myocardial infarction (MI) to better understand the acute phase of this cardiac event. Different enzymes are released into the bloodstream at various times after myocardial tissue damage, serving as important biomarkers for diagnosing MI. Among the listed enzymes, which one is known to elevate first in the bloodstream following a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Creatine kinase

 

Option C.

 

  • Serum CK value starts to rise within 3–6 hours of myocardial infarction.
  • Hence CK estimation is very useful to detect early cases, where ECG changes may be ambiguous and a second peak may indicate another ischemic episode.
  • It is not increased in hemolysis or in CCF and therefore CK has an advantage over LDH.
  • The area under the peak and slope of initial rise are proportional to the size of infarct.

 

Iso-enzymes of CK:

 

  • CK is a dimer, has 2 subunits called B for brain and M for muscle. Therefore, three iso-enzymes are seen in circulation.
  • Normally CK2 (heart iso-enzyme) is only 5% of the total activity and even doubling of the value of CK2 (MB) iso-enzyme may not be detected, if the total value of CK alone is estimated.

 

 

  • So, the estimation of MB-isoenzyme is the best diagnostic marker in myocardial infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspartate transaminase: While aspartate transaminase (AST) levels can increase in myocardial infarction, they are less specific and tend to rise later than creatine kinase, making AST a less useful marker for the early diagnosis of MI.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels can also be elevated in myocardial infarction, but this enzyme typically peaks several days after the onset of symptoms, making it useful for late diagnosis but not for early detection.

 

Option D. Alanine aminotransferase: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is more specific to liver tissue, and while it may rise in cases of extensive muscle damage, it is not a primary biomarker for myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine kinase (CK), particularly the CK-MB (creatine kinase, muscle-brain) isoform, is one of the earliest enzymes to rise following myocardial infarction. Its levels can begin to increase within 4 to 6 hours after the onset of MI, peaking at 12 to 24 hours, making it a crucial early marker for acute myocardial injury.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 302.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe pain in the epigastric and periumbilical region, which radiates to the back. H/O 3 episodes of vomiting and low grade fever. He has been a chronic alcoholic for the past 20 years. On palpation, the abdomen was distended and tender. On auscultation, bowel sounds - absent. Blood investigations: Serum amylase: 240 U/L (normal is 30 to 100 U/L) and Serum lipase: 200 U/L (normal is 15 to 80 U/L). Which of the following parameters has more advantage over other investigations in diagnosing the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Serum lipas

 

Option B.

 

  • It is a case of acute pancreatitis, where premature activation of trypsinogen inside the pancreas will result in the autodigestion of pancreatic cells.
  • It is a life-threatening condition.
  • Serum lipase is highly elevated in acute pancreatitis and persists for 7 – 14 days.
  • Thus, its level remains elevated for a longer period than amylase and also lipase is not increased in salivary diseases. Hence, lipase estimation has an advantage over amylase.
  • Moderately increased in carcinoma of pancreas, biliary diseases and perforating peptic ulcers.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Serum amylase is the major enzyme which digests starch, contains the P (pancreatic) and S (salivary) iso-enzymes. Normal amylase level in serum is 50–120 units and the level rises within 5 hours of the onset of acute pancreatitis → reaches a peak within 12 hours → returns to normal within 2–4 days of attack → when urinary amylase level rises.

Serum amylase is mildly increased in cholecystitis, peptic ulcer, diseases of mesentery and

obstruction of intestine and no significant changes or only mild elevation is noticed in chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Pancreatic elastase: Test for the diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency, done by ELISA method and a value of >200 mg in stool sample indicates normal exocrine pancreatic function and values <200 mg indicates exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

 

Option D. Pancreatic trypsin: It is a simple screening test to access the trypsin activity of feces done using serial dilutions of stool extract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum lipase is generally considered a more specific and reliable marker for diagnosing acute pancreatitis compared to serum amylase. Lipase levels remain elevated for a longer duration than amylase levels and are more specific to the pancreas.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 308, 358.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is commonly measured using peroxidase enzyme activity
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glucose 

 

Option D.

 

Peroxidase enzymes are used in the enzymatic assay for glucose measurement. In these assays, peroxidase catalyzes a reaction in the presence of hydrogen peroxide, leading to a color change. The change in color intensity is proportional to the concentration of glucose in the blood sample, allowing for its quantification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Triglycerides: The measurement of triglycerides typically involves lipase for hydrolysis, not peroxidase.

 

Option B. Uric acid: For uric acid measurement, uricase is the enzyme commonly utilized, which catalyzes the oxidation of uric acid to allantoin.

 

Option C. Creatinine: Creatinine assays usually do not involve peroxidase; instead, methods such as the Jaffe reaction are commonly employed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 67.

questions.text: A 35 year old man complains of fatigue and abdominal pain. O/E: Hepatomegaly + Laboratory results: Serum AST – 125 U/L, ALT – 82 U/L, ALP – 66 U/L, GGT– 170 U/L, Bilirubin – 1.0 mg/dL, glucose – 62 mg/dL, Uric acid – 8.0 mg/dL, CBC and urinalysis were normal. Which of the following markers help in monitoring alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carbohydrate deficient transferrin

 

Option C.

 

Laboratory Findings in Chronic Alcoholism

 

  • Increased serum levels of gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) and alanine transaminase (ALT).
  • Decreased aldehyde dehydrogenase activity (in liver cells and RBCs): The best marker for alcohol abuse.
  • Carbohydrate deficient transferrin level in blood: Highly sensitive marker for chronic alcohol abuse.

 

The important markers for monitoring alcoholism

 

  • Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP)
  • Serum glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH)
  • Serum Carbohydrate deficient transferrin
  • RBC acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lactate dehydrogenase: While LDH levels can be elevated in liver disease, they are not specific for alcohol-related liver damage and can be elevated in a variety of conditions affecting the liver and other tissues.

 

Option B. Glutamate hydrolase: Glutamate hydrolase (also known as glutaminase) is not a standard marker for alcoholism and is not typically used in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin (CDT) is a specific biomarker for chronic alcohol consumption. Elevated levels of CDT in the blood can indicate excessive alcohol intake over a prolonged period. Unlike other liver function tests, CDT is less likely to be elevated due to non-alcohol-related liver diseases and thus serves as a more specific indicator of alcoholism.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 141.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match between the tumor markers and the types of cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

Option C:

 

1. Prostatic acid phosphatase: This enzyme was historically used as a tumor marker for prostate cancer, making 1-c the correct pairing.

 

2. Alkaline phosphatase: Elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase are often associated with bone metastasis, which can occur in various cancers, including prostate cancer when it spreads to the bone, making 2-d the correct pairing.

 

3. Neuron specific enolase: This is a marker that can be elevated in neuroendocrine tumors, including small-cell lung carcinoma, making 3-a the correct pairing.

 

4. Lactate dehydrogenase: LDH can be elevated in many types of cancer, but it is particularly noted to be a marker in germ cell tumors and some lymphomas, making 4-b the correct pairing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 715.

questions.text: A laboratory technician is preparing to perform various immunodiffusion assays and is reviewing the materials needed for the procedures. Immunodiffusion assays commonly utilize antibodies conjugated to enzymes or molecules that facilitate detection. The technician is assessing the inventory and noting which conjugates are typically used in these assays. Based on standard laboratory practices, which of the following reagents is NOT commonly used as a conjugate to antibodies in immunodiffusion assays?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Riboflavin

 

Option C:

 

In immunodiffusion assays, antibodies are often conjugated to enzymes like alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and horseradish peroxidase (HRP) or to molecules like biotin, which can be part of a detection system (e.g., avidin-biotin complex). These conjugates facilitate the visualization of the antibody-antigen complexes. Riboflavin, a vitamin, is not typically used as a conjugate in these assays due to its lack of enzymatic activity or specific binding properties that would enable detection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): ALP is commonly used as an enzyme conjugate in immunoassays due to its ability to catalyze the conversion of substrates to detectable products.

 

Option B. Horseradish peroxidase (HRP): HRP is another enzyme widely used as a conjugate in immunoassays for its catalytic activity in producing detectable signals from substrates.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin is used as a conjugate because of its strong binding affinity for avidin or streptavidin, which can be part of a detection system in immunoassays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immunodiffusion assays will use antibodies conjugated with the enzymes such as alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and horseradish peroxidase (HRP).
  • Also antibodies conjugated with reagents like fluorescein isothiocyanate and labelled with biotin are used.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 741

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was admitted in the casualty with crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm and was diagnosed to have a heart attack. His cholesterol is 430 mg/dL despite prior use of statin medicines and has familial hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following treatments should be considered in the acute management of his heart attack?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tissue plasminogen activator infusion

 

Option D:

 

  • Plasmin is activated by proteolytic cleavage of plasminogen (zymogen) by tissue plasminogen activator (tPA).
  • Plasmin hydrolyzes fibrin clots to soluble products and is used to dissolve clots in coronary arteries →myocardial infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C. Platelets, thrombin, and fibrinogen:

 

  • Promote clotting through the intrinsic pathway and is contraindicated in myocardial infarction.
  • Platelets form a plug at the site of bleeding →bind prothrombin →facilitate its conversion to thrombin.
  • Fibrinogen is the substrate on which the thrombin acts to yield the fibrin mesh of blood clots.

 

Option B. Heparin is a mucopolysaccharide which inhibits the formation of clots but cannot dissolve it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the acute management of a myocardial infarction, tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) infusion is used to dissolve the thrombus blocking the coronary artery, thereby restoring blood flow to the heart muscle. tPA is a thrombolytic agent and is appropriate in certain cases of acute myocardial infarction, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 433.
